newsitem.title: INDIA: Profit squeeze seen at India's Reliance.
newsitem.headline: Profit squeeze seen at India's Reliance.

text.p: India's Reliance Industries is expected to announce sharply lower profits for the first half due to higher costs, lower product prices and flat volume growth, analysts said on Wednesday.
The Indian petrochemicals giant will unveil its first-half results for 1996/97 (April-March) on Friday.
"The profits are going to be sharply down," said Jal Irani, petrochemicals analyst at Jardine Fleming India Broking.
Prices of the company's products were down by 20-25 percent, while its raw material costs, with the exception of ethylene, had gone up, he said.

Profits would also be hit by a new 12.9 percent minimum tax on companies that previously paid no taxes. The levy would eat up nearly 1.5 billion rupees ($42 million) of the firm's profits for the full year ending March 31, 1997, analysts said.
Reliance grew into India's largest private sector company by taking advantage of tax breaks on new investments.

Analysts forecast Reliance's net profit to fall by an average of 25.8 percent to 4.7 billion rupees ($131.8 million) in the first half against 6.3 billion in the year-ago period, a Reuter poll of 14 securities houses showed last month.
One analyst projected the net profit to hit 4.0 billion rupees while another saw it at 6.2 billion.
The poll forecast sales to fall 21.1 percent to an average 31.3 billion rupees.
"The fall (in net profit) should be much more (than 25.8 percent)," an analyst at a foreign securities firm said.
Reliance could beat the projections if it reports a big jump in other income. "Otherwise, the writing is on the wall," he said.
Other income usually are earnings from investments in securities or profit from sale of securities, both unrelated to the company's main business.
Some analysts believe that traders have taken into account the expected setback, leaving little surprise in store.
"Everybody has factored the disappointment," said Rupa Bose, strategist at Paribas Capital Markets. "It's a disappointment that's expected."
Reliance shares were trading at 188.75 rupees on Wednesday afternoon at the Bombay Stock Exchange -- down 29.3 percent from 267.0 year's high reached on May 2.
Though adverse market conditions would impact Reliance's working, the performance would not be too bad, she said.
"What I see is really a small erosion ... less than 10 percent (fall in profits) for the year," Bose said. "I'm not going with the 30-40 percent fall some people talk of."
